div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: MINISTRY OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION.
div.p: 'Though the Ministry of Public Instraction has come in for a good deal of criticism this year it has accomplished much under its néw Mixister. The establishment 'of numerous kuttabs, the institution of a special department at cal and agricultural education, the revival of the educational mission to Europe, the increase in the teaching staff and the continued improvement of the organisation of the Ministry are all admirable achievements, and we shall look with interest to next autumn's changes. Saad Pasha Zagloul afd Mr. Dunlop form a strong combination atthe Ministry. Mr. Dunlop's knowledge of detail and the Minister's progressive energy have achieved great -results, and despite our Nationalist' critics we doubt whether any of the would-be teachers of the Ministry could have done better.

The question of the use of Arabic remains to be discussed. There we think that Mr. Dunlop's attitude of non possumus requires some modification, We do not say that it, is practically possible to use Arabic to-day or to-morrow, as the sole medium for instruction, but we do hold that there is nothing in the language that makes it unfit for such' use. Even if it be impossible to teach say electricity or advanced chemistryin Arabit, there can be no' pretence that a knowledge of history, geography, the moral sciences, logié and mathematics cannot be imparted in the language of Avicenna. The language can surely adapt itself to modern ideas and can annex such scientific or philosophical terms as were unknown, to the diyines and philosophers of the early 'middle ages. In spoken Arabic we find words \annexed and declined, e.g. farwardplur. fararid (forwards) gol pl. agwal (goal), and why should not the literary tongue annex the Greek and Latin scientific terminol ployed by the great majority of the European nations? In fact we are inclined to think that Egypt would be the gainer if all Arabic scientific and philosophic terms that do not derive from the Greek and Latin were jettisoned, on the ground that a common scientific vocabulary is of great advantage to iptertiational intercourse. English, though a Teutonic language, has gone to Greek and Latin forits scientific vocabulary, with the result that an slishman with but a moderate knowledge of French or Italian is in a better position to understand a French or Italian: Scientific treatise than a German, who has his own scientific vocabulary based upon the development of Teutonic, not of Latin or Greek ropt. words. We cares the French 'raison'; the German must say 'vernunft'; English and 'representation', Germans of 'vorstellung.' We commend this suggestion to our Nationalist crities, who should be able to discuss it without excessive bias, since it aims at bringing Arabic into line with some of the great Etropéan* tongues so far as part of its yocabulary ig concerned.

div.head: Bains du Mex.
div.p: The opening of the Bains du Mex will take place on Friday. The last train will leave Mex at 1 a.m.

div.head: Khedivial Library.
div.p: From July 1 to September 30 the Khedivial Library, Cairo, will be open to the public from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m.

div.head: Sudden Death.
div.p: A Syrian woman who was alking along the street yesterday afternoon suddenly dropped down in a fit and died in a few minutes.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P. and O.) will be distributed at the Alexandria post office at half past four this afternoon.

div.head: Public Health Department
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has authorised Drs. G. Xydis and Mohamned Shakin, and Messrs. Abdel Hamid Zeki, and Abdel Ghani Negib, vetinary, surgeons to practise in Egypt.

div.head: Fatal Cart Accident.
div.p: A Bulgarian milkman was driving his cart along Moharrem Bey at a rapid pace, when his horse fell and the man was thrown to the ground. A cab ran over the man's leg, and he died a short while after the accident.

div.head: Chimney on Fire.
div.p: At half past eight the Fire Brigade received notice that a chimney of a bakery in the Me-nayer quarter was on fire. They promptly arrived on the scene and in half an hour's time extinguished the fire with chemical ex-tinguishers.

div.head: The Motor-Car Accident.
div.p: The motor-car accident, which we reported yesterday, has resulted fatally, the girl haviing succumbed to the injuries she received. A post-mortem examination was made yesterday afternoon, and the girl was buried this morning.

div.head: THE "DE VERE" FUND.
div.p: The many readers of the "Egyptian Gazette" who so kindly subscribed five years ago to the fund raised in Egypt on behalf of the children of the late 'Sergt. Maj' De Vere, may be interestad to know that at a meeting of the trustees held on the 10th inst. at the Masonic Hall, Sharia Bulak, Cairo (by kind permission of Idris Bey Ragheb) satisfactory news of the children was communicated.

The elder girl is at present with her husband and his regiment in India} the younger is learning the useful art of dressmaking ; all the boys promise to follow their father's career, the eldest at present serving as trumpeter in the 14th Hussars in Ireland, and the two younger being educated at the Duke of York's Military school.
The fund, including a recent subscription of LE 40 from the Grand Lodge of Egypt, shows a balance of LB. 370.

div.head:
C.M.S. SCHOOLWORK
CAIRO BOYS' SCHOOL.
div.p: The problem of -educational. work among boys in Egypt, from a mission point of view, has for some time been a very. serious one The widespreadness, excellence, and cheapness of: the government system, the multiplicity_of still cheaper Moslem and Coptic privaté schools of all grades, standards, and sizes, made it increasingly difficult for a mission school in a capital like Cairo to.find a standing, except by the expenditure of money to an extent that does not seem warranted. These difficulties, which had been increasing year after year, culminated this year, and the con- ference, a stewards accountable fdr money snbseribed, often as the result of such hard effort in England, felt bound, with a full sense of the grave responsibility of taking such a step, to close thé boys' school in Sharia Mohamed Ali—the very oldest branch of our work in Egypt.

In many 'respects the schiool was at the very time of its\) losing more efficient than it had ever been :'yet the results it bore did not seem to warrant the increased expenditure foreseen as necessary in the immediate future. However keen be the natural regret for the disappearatice of an old branch of work, we believe, and we know that every supporter of missions will iigree, that considerations of true economy; 'in the highest and broadest sense of that te?m, must be-always/paramount, and that, beyond all things, the stewards of the (M.S. are bound to see that its funds are applied to the very fallest advantagé. There can be no doubt that what is saved by such right economies will enable other and more fruitful work to be ini- tiated by the C.M.S. mission in Egypt.

The Boys' School in Old Gairo, under the superintendence of Mr Toop, continues to improve 'in every way, in efficiency, and in results on the boys, who are increasing both in quantity and quality. One boy succeeded in sbtaining the Primary Certificate this year, a fact which is sure. to tell excellently on the schoo! during 1906-7. The prospect is here therefore. distinctly encouraging.
(From the (C.M.S. report).

div.head:
EARL DUNDONALD RESIGNS.
SUCCEEDED BY BADEN-POWELL
div.p: London, Wednesday.
Earl Dundonald's retirement from the Army is announced, Major-General Baden-Powell has been appointed Lieutenant General vice Earl Dundonald.

div.head:
NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
BANK BUILDINGS' ALTERATIONS.
div.p: Considerable alterations are being carried on inthe National Bank at Cairo, where the workmen are engayed in enlarging the space available for the staff, a part of which has been temporarily transferred to the' upper storey of the building, which, in the time of the late Sir Elwin Palmer, was used as the Bank Governor's residence. The building adjoining the Bank at the corner of Sharia Kasr el-Nil and Sharia Zervudachi, which was purchased by the National Bank some 'eight months ago, is shortly to come dowitfjo allow'of a farther addition to the present Bank building.

The new Mousky branch building of 'the Bank, the building of which has been greatly hindered by its difficult position, will, we understand, be completed in three to four months' time. As soon as the various sites can be obtained the Bank will construct agencies in every moudirieh town of Upper and' Lower Egypt, 'The Khartoum branch of the bank is undérgoing structural alterations and being considerably enlarged.

div.head: WHITE SLAVE TRAFFIC.
div.p: A Cairo contemporary reports that -some days ago, » young girl, hardly sixteen years ot age, presented herself befére a doctor for medi- eal attendance. She was 'accompanied by a person of unfayourable appearance. The doctor on diagnosing her illness explained the ease to her, and the child burst into tears, throwing herself at the doctor's feet, she bexged him not only to cure her, but to allow her to stop in his house, so that She might be saved. The story the girl told was follows :-

"She was an orphan, friendless, and with- out -protector in Pirmus, her natiye. town. Fifteen days ago she came to Alexandria to take up/a situation as servant. The person who accQmpanied her to the doctor's met her ron the quay.on her arrival at Alexandria. Under pretext of finding her "a good: situation she took her to a house of ill-repute where she sold herto the "patronne."
The doctor and his wife, on hearing the girl's pitiable story promised' to keep her and turned ont the person who had brought her anil who refused to leave her.

An hour later the woman returned to the doctor's house and threaterfed the doctor that she would have thegirlremoved by foree by her confederates.' The doctor hurriedly sent-off 'a letter to the Greek consul-general to whom he exposed the facts: of the case, begging him to undertake the protection of the. girl. .Mr. Scotidis it is said categorically: refused to occupy himself with the affair. The girl has, therefore, been placed -in the Friedrich Wilhelm home, through the generosity ofthe doctor.

'It' is almost impossible to believe' such a story regarding the Action of the consul- general in the matter,-and we trust that every effort will be shade to establish' the true facts of the case and put them before the public, for the charge could hardly be a more serious One, and will cause great public comment

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex-pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits-free discussion.

div.head: AT THE RACES.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—Your columns .are not the, place tox disenss questions of Christian charity, but "Cairene's" remarks, foolish and superficial as they are, may lead astray the "baser sort." "Go and sin no more" was the command, and advice proetping deeply of the highest charity. To talk Of brutalising and degrading still urther, by tinion from the course is rank nonsensé. Repentant unfortunates do not flaunt themselves at races, and the last course to be recommended by those who would earnestly and willingly hold out 'a helping hand would be the race course.

Because some members of the club ichjeot to the present condition of things, there need be no suggestion: of Pharasaic drawing in of the skirts from pollution. Caiféne's cloaking over profligacy and allowing undesirables to rab shoulders with society savours much more of acquiesence than anything else, and the re- forming effect is difficult to grasp. Repentence. in sackeloth and askes finds Jittle place in his scheme of an upward grade movement.

The hypocrisy of vice is as common as the hypocrisy of virtwe, and better have a frank avowal of indifference to the aspects of the races than a pretence that a pléeasure seeking assembly may prove an elevating méans ot raising the unfortunates.
"Cairene" had better find means to the same end and he will not lack support.
Yours truly,
Anti-Humbug

div.head: THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
div.p: Burbaneddin Bey one of his Majesty's chamberlains, after delivering the Iinperial firman granting the ministerial grade. to his Excellency Shukri Pasha, Governor General of the Vilayet of Syria, returned to Constantinople by the Messageries last' week. This is possibly an expression of the Imperial pleasure at the good work that/hasilately been done on | the Hedjaz Railway, whose 'headquarters He's | is well-known, ut Dathascus, the, capital of the said Vilayet.

In this connection it may not be deyoid.of interest to mention the fact that Taher Effendi, chief accountant ofthe'Hamidieh Hedjaz Rail- way, has, in company with: certain officials, repaired recently to the extreme stations on the line topay to the Imperial soldiers the arrears of four months' wages, together with certain gratuities granted by his Majesty the Sultan.

div.head: Izzet Pasha.
div.p: Izzet Pash, of diplomatic fame, has bought th eold seraglio of Marje at Damascus, and intends now building in its place a palatial edifice destined in great part for offices to th egreat Ottoman administration such as the Imperial Ottoman Bank, the Dette Publique, etc. An agreement is said to have been practically concluded with a good firm of contractors at Beyrout for a million francs.

div.head: Damascus Electric Tramway.
div.p: Consequent on the fatal accidents that have repeatedly taken place on the electric tramway line at Damascus, and which have determined once a violent outbreak of popular revolt, it has been at last decided to enlarge the streets along which the lines pass to a reasonable width. Such a measure of public safety should have been taken at the outset without waiting for the sacrifice of human life to justify it. Fortunately in Beyrout the prescribed width is such as to preclude the possibility of such overcrowding as has been taking place in the narrow streets of Damascus with such re-grettable results.

div.head:
ROUND THE WORLD.
VISIT OF A GLOBE-TROTTER.
div.p: Mr. Joseph Gerard, a Frenchman of 35 years, who started from Brussels on the Ist March 1901 on a walking tour round the world for a wager, is: paying a second visit to Alexandria, he having been here before in October .1905. He is léaving to-morrow, at 8a.m for Port Said, via T'antah, and will then walk to Sueg, where he will embark for Aden. From Aden lis itinerary will be as. follows :— Colombo, Fremantle, Adelaide, Sydney, Auck- land, and finally San Franciseo, where he will remam. Mr. Gerard left Brusséls without a penny in. his pocket and: pays his expenses by selling picture postcards of himself, He was to have completed his journey in thiree years *but was stricken down with. fever in Shanghai and had consequently to returm to France to recuperate and "so lost his Bet. On recovery, he started again, however, without bet, but paid a second visit to France in consequence of the death of a relative He has been globe-trotting, more or less, for six years,

div.head: EXCESSIVE POLITENESS.
div.p: "Two cases of recent date have occurred in Egypt to shew the error, or sometimes the danger, of being excessively polite, especially when an Egyptian carries-his zeal too far. 'The first was the case ofa notable in Lower Egypt who wished to honour some of his English guests and helped to bring about a possible calamity' Hassan Bey Zaid is a wealthy notable, well known for his generosity in enter: taining English guests of the official type. Engineers of the Irrigation Departinent, inspectors of the various Ministries, and offi- cers.avail themselves of his generosity from time to time. The last to be welcomed was a certain employé of Cook's _ tourist office in Cairo. This gentleman wished to go pigeon shooting as usual and his host was generous in giving him recommendations to the surrounding villagers. He even shewed generosity in. describing the man as a great and important Englishman. This made the villagers think him the Financial Adviser and the error led to heated and venomous comments in "Al-Moayad", a paper which claims moderation for its tone, but is practically a rabid enemy to everything except its own ends. The mere rumour that the Financial Adviser was in the wrong aroused a storm of protests and yapourings of the most detestable kind.

"The other case of too much zeal or flattery was that of the clerk who invited the emdehs and notables of Minia to bid farewell to his chief, an inspector of the Ministry of Interior, at the station. He sent round cards in his own name for the purpose, and was instrumental in making "Al-Moayad" show his icn once again by denouncing the British offieisls in his wily and mischievous style. In this case it transpired that the official attacked had no share in the offence and another proof, if proof was wanting, was given on the vaunted "moderation" of the paper which leads the anti- foreign and anti-reform party in these days."

div.head: HARVEST LABOUR.
div.p: Harvest labour remains unprecedently high : 25 cp. per day and food being not un-common for men-and 15 cp. and food for women. Meanwhile the new barley is selling at 14 cp. per kilo. Merchants are selling a fair quantity to England and are taking proper care to thoroughly clean the grain-for which purpose machines have been imported.
Teh crop of cvetches is believed to be small-and prices in the autumn will probably be high.

div.head: E.T.C. Rates.
div.p: The Eastern Telegraph Company has taken what is thought to be the wise step of lower-ing their rates for inland message. Hitherto 1/10d per 20 words has been the charge. From the 1st instant the rate is 6d for six words.

div.head: Ice Delivery.
div.p: Ice is now being regularly delivered to Nicosia from Larnaca, and the ususal supplies of snow form the "snow pits" in Mt. Troodos are therefore not needed. The possibility of obtaining ice at a moderate price is a welcome boon.

div.head: Famagusta Fair.
div.p: On the 20th June the annual St. George's Fair will be held at Famagusta, when ponies, mules and donkeys will as usual be sent in for sale from many parts of the Island.

div.head: A JOURNEY THROUGH AFRICA.
div.p: At the Royal Institution last week 'Mr. 'A.H. 'Savage Latdorgaye a lecture on his "Reeent Journey through "Africa." Sir J Crichton 'Browne was in the chair, and there was a crowded audience. Mr. Landor said it took him 364 days' hard marching to cross Africa at its widest part, and the total distance {travelled amounted to some 8,500 statute miles, Starting from Djibuti, in Frehch Somali- 'land, he crossed Abyssinia in a South-westerly direction as far ag the Sobat river. 'Thence he made his.way tothe Nile some 60 or 70-miles iniles souh of Fashoda, and continuing his journey across the Bahr-el-Ghaval, proceeded 'through the forest down to the Mbomu and Ubangi-rivers in the French Congo. He also visited thé Congo Free State. Leaving the Ubangi at a point about the fifth parallel of latitude north he marched in a north-easterly, direetion towards Lake Chad, -which he crossed, and after making a large détour towards the east and. visiting some of the tribes to the north of the lake, he passed through the desert to Tomboetn, whence he crossed over to the Senegal till Cape Verde, the most - westerly point in Africa, was' reached. He said that during the journey he availed himself pf every possible means_af locomotion, except a flying machine, At no time did he have 'more than 30 pack animals and some 40 men, but he had hardly gone one-third of the way when he found himself deserted'in the most difficult part of the journey by all his men except one faithful Somali, with whom he managed to take the >-entire caravan across the forest during the season of the heavy rains. For the greater part of the time the expedition was in very unhealthy regions where malarial fever was rampant. But lie cafried no medicine to to speak of, used no filters for the water, and was not particular about mosquito bites ; nor did he adopt any of the precautions suggested hy the medical profession, 'The result was that he returned to England in excellent health, He carried no fire arms or weapons of any kind, and though he armed his! men with repeating rifles, he never gave them any cartridges, There were no other white men in his expedition, which. was undertaken at his own risk and expense. 'I'he lecture was illustrated with a large number of lantern slides.

div.head: EGYPTICA.
div.p: By Joseph Offord.

In the important collection of Greek papyri from Hitbeh in the Fayoum, the introductory chapter by Messrs. Grenfell. and Hunt jneiden- tally affords a remarkable proof of the very slight alteration that must have taken plaee in the land surface of Egypt along the Titonal of the Nile'for over 2,000 years.

The ruins of the ancient city of Hibeh are situated upon the East bank of the Nile between Benesuéfand Shékh Fadl,and opposite to the old walls, which are upon the river, bank separated by a narrow channel, which in summer becomes almost waterless, - is a long low island stretching for some two miles. Now the island is often mentioned 'in Demotic papyri dating back as far as Darius,so that there has practically not been any-change in the physical geography of this site upon the Nile since the Persian period.

Among these I eck papyri is one short letter Fuss one friend to another which bring's vividly before us the domestic life 6f Greek settlers under the Ptolemies, and illus- trates the old adage "there isnot anything' new under the sun," for excepting an allusion toa slave the lette: might'almost haye been written by an inhabitant of Ryypt, yesterday. The writer of the epistley Damophon, was evidently about to hold a festival and banquét at his residence and is desirous of providing amuse- ment and good. cheer for his guests. He Says, "Make eyery effort to send me the flute player Petous, with both the Phrygian. flutes and the rest, and if any expense is necessary, pay it and you shall recover it from me, Send me also Zenobius the effeminate wiwth a drum, cymbals and castanets for he is wanted by the women for the sacrified; and let him wear As- fine clothes as possible Get the kid also from Aristion and send it to me, and if you haye arrested the slaye deliver him to Sempthens to bring him to me. Send meas many cheeses | as.you can , a new jar ; vegetables of all kinds,' some delicacies. Good bye. Put them on'board with the guards bringing the boat to Ptol- emaeus".

Another, Ptolemaic papyrus dated B, C. 268 is interesting because giving the complete legal engrossment of an agreement for bail. In this case there were two sureties, the action was a civil one, being for recovery of a debt'and 'the sureties agreed either to produce their man, a certain Timocles, for trial before the strategus at/Heracleopolis, or failing to do so, shall pay the suitor 300 drachmae, the amount his claim, No date is fixed for the trial and production of the defendant and so it would doubtless be Officially announced and communicated to the two sureties by letter

The next papyrus, a similar case of bail, however with only one surety gives notice that the baillee shall be forthcoming on the 13th day of the month Pharmonthi in the same yearas the date of the contract of surety.

Many contracts, or guarantees of fidelity, of the kind in the legal papyri are not however connected with law' suits, but are sureties for government ofticials, especially. contractors for tax collection, or "tax farmers."

It would appear that these appointments, which doubtless were lucrative and conse- quently in demand, were only obtainable if ample sureties for the handing over to the administration of the sum promised to be gathered in, were forthcoming.

The modern system of levying rates to support sanitary municipal inspectors, and analyists, was carcied further in Graeco-Roman Egypt, where a tax was levied to pay the district. medical man. 'These imposts for the maintenance of public physicians are frequently referred to in the papyri, and appear to have been payable especially by the military settlers. The following documents tersely explains this "... a Cyrenean private of Zoilus' troop. to Eucarpus physician, greeting. It Has been orderect that I shall pay you 10 artabal of olyra, or 4 drachme as the physioten tax (iatriconfor the 38th year. "
" These I will pay you in the month Daisus, and if I fail to pay you 10 artabal of olyra, or 4 drachma as the physician tax (iatricon) for the 38th year. "

The contents of papyrus number 110 have a very modern appearance, for they are the record of the receipt, and delivery, of re-gistered letters by the postmen or messen-gers. Several of the documents were for the king himself and had came from the "elephant country" probably above Khartoum. But the monarch has im-ported elephants and was rearing them in Egypt, for a letter of his is recited as being addressed to "Demetrius the officer in charge of supplies for the elephants in the Thebaid."

div.head:
A.S.C.
AMATEUR RACE MEETING.
div.p: The publication of the entries for the Ama-teur Race Meeting to be held on Saturday next are unavoidably postponed until to-morrow.
The entries for the hurdle race being in-sufficient the race will not take place.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor sailed yesterday for Liverpool via Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo, including 8,258 bales cotton and 10,006 bags onions.
The Ellerman liner Bulgarian arrives at Liverpool yesterday morning.
The S.S. Belgian Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Dunkirk on the 10th inst. and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 27th inst.

div.head: PERAONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Saba Pasha is leaving for Europe to-morrow by the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Imperator.
Noury Bey, 1st Sevretary to Elg Ghazi Ahmed Mukhtar Pasha, has arrived and will act as High Commmissioner of the Porte, during the absence of Mukhtar Pasha.
Count and Countess de Mathuisieulx left for Malta yesterday by the Moss S.S. Tabor.
Colonel J. Magill, M.D., CB., A.M.S., offi-ciating principal medical officer, is leaving for Cyprus next week to make the annual inspec-tion of barracks at that station.

Capt. and Brevet Major J.E. Pine-Coffin, D.S.O., Royal North Laneashire Regiment, embarked in the P. and O. S.S. India, for passage to London (Tilbury), on termination of appointment as Commandant, Monnted Infantry in Egypt.
Mr. Critchley, manager of the Imperial Ottoman Bank, will not go on leave on Satur-day, as announced by us yesterday.
Lieutenant the Hon. M. St.A.T. St. John, King's Own Scottish Borderers, has, at the recommendation of a medical board, been granted an extension of leave to July 23.
Lieutenant V.M.C. Napier, R.H.A., has been granted three months' leave of absence from the 18th inst.
Mrs. Hardy, wife of Major F.W. Hardy, R.A.M.C., has left for England with her daughter by the P. & O. S.S. Borneo.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: La Delegation Municipale s'est reunie hier apres-midi sous la presidence de S.E. Schiess Pacha.
Elle a examine une derande de M. Degiarde tendant a installer un marche dans la rue Saleh-el-Din. Cette demande a ete ren voyee a l'etude des services technique et sanitaire.

- La Delegation a autorise sous certaines conditions etablies par l'Ingenieur en echef et a titre provisoire la Societe des Presses alle-mandes a construire une passerelle entre deux Chounahs a Minet-el-Bassal.

- Elle a decide de demander certains renseignements complementaires, avant d'exa-miner une demande present-e par la Societe des Entreprises Urbaines et Rurales pour la cession de deux rues pres de Moharrem Bey.

- La Delegation a renvoye aux services oiur rapport, avvant de prendre une decision, une demande de la Societe des Entreprises Urbai-nes et Rurales, tendnant au remblai du Canal Farkha, et a son remplacement par un aquedue.
_ Elle a adjuge a M. T. Suzzarini la fourni-ture de 20,000 metres carres de dalles.
- Sur la proposition de l'Inspecteur Sani-taire, la Delegation a decide d'aggraver les penalites pour l'abatage clandestin, afin de reprimer les nombreuses fraudes commises.

- La Delegation a pris note de l'arret de la Cour rendu en sa faveur, confirmant le juge-ment de premiere instance, dans l'affaire Bismot, au sujet de la propriete de certaines parcelles de terrain a Chatby.

- En vue de l'etablissement d'un marche aux poissons, la Delegation, sous reserve d'une decision ulterieure a prendre a ce sujet, a decide de se reserver, d'ores et deja, sur les nouveaux quais, la parcelle No. 39 pour l'eta-blissement de ce marche.

- Sur la proposition de l'Administration, la Delegation a decide l'achat d'un materiel de sauvetage en cas d'accident, et demandera a cet effet, l'ouverture d'un credit de 400 Livres. Ce materiel sera confie an service des pompiers.
- La Delegation a pris note, en dernier lieu, de l'etat des recettes et des depenses du ler Janvier au 31 Mai 1907.

div.head: Cinculaire H. De Vries et Bouginy
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de lescompte libre 4 Londres se maintient' 4 38 3/4 pour cent. Au Stock Ex- change, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié 4837/8, de méme que I'Unifiée A 100 1/4. La National Bank a encore perdu 1/8 4 22 1/8, ainsi que la Daira'Sanieh 4 14 7/8. L'Agricole s'est tenue & son cours précédent, soit 8 1/4. La Delta Light a avaneé de 1/8 4:9 7/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est de- meuré inchangé 4 705. La Banque d'Athénes a regagné 1 franc a 127.

Ici, nous avons. eu, & matin, une séance franchemient mauyaise. 'Impressionné par les ventes effectuées par. des établissements de crédit pour compte de clients obligés & liquider leur situation, 'par la réaction, pourtant . bien naturelle, des -pmx du coton aprés la hausse eontinue de ces jours derniers, ainsi que par toutes espéces de racontars pessimistes, le marché s'est laissé aller 4 la dérive et a fait le jeu du groupe baissier. Nous avons en aingi une sorte de petite panique qui, il faut l'es- pérer, n'aura pas, sinonde lendemain,du moins des suites graves pour la position de place. Toujours est-il que la partie est devenue belle pour le Syndicat s'il -veut'finalemententrer en seéne et enrayer cette nouvelle dépression, qué d'aucun I'accusent, bien a tort, d'avoir déter- minéé afin de relever. pratiquement des cours ramenés au plus bas niveau possible. Au reste, le Syndicat a bon dos et tout le monde se plait} & taper dessus, & commencer' par ceux: qui, naguére encore, .s¢ refusaient 4 adinettre -|'e- xistéence réelle de cé consortium, qu'ils pro- clamaient, par conséquent, incapable de faire soit le beau temps, soit la pluie. Or, les nnages s'amoncelant 4 'horizon, l'on congoit que les inerédules "eux-mémes soient. de mauvaise humeur.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na- tional Bank, que nous avions laissée hier 4-224 1/16, areculé & 21 1/2. L'Agricole, d'ordinaire si ténace, a élleméme cédé environ 3/16 a 8 1/16-1/8. La Cassa di Sconto a rétrogradé a 145.

Le Crédit Foncier 4 fiéchi 4 700; par suite de Vapproche du tirage, les obligations a lots anciennes sont remontees a 325 et les nou- velles 4 270. La Daira est descendue a 14 3/4. La Nile Land est revenue a 20. Les fondateurs Wardan Estate ont encore perdu une 1/2 livre 47 1/2. L''Union Fonciére s'est alourdie a 5; les Allotmprts-a-2 1/16 et leur part a, 50.
La Delta-Light a laissé 1/84 9 3/4 et les Automobiles 1/4 a 3.
Dans le groupédées valeurs hoteliérés, Nungovich ont été tamenés a 1717 1/4, Egyptian 4 6, les Upper Egypt a 2 7/8 et National a 2 5 8.
Parmi es petites valeurs, la Delta Land a faibli a 2, les Estates 4 1-1 1/16 et les Salt and Soda 4 19 sh.
Tut le restant de la cote est a l'avenant.

Les journaux financiers d'Europe commen- cent a s'intéresser' viyement a la crise passa- gere que traverse le marché égyptien. Voici ce que nous lisonsdans le dernier numéro de la "Cote Hebdomadaire " d'Anvers :

" La prospérité étonnante de l'Egypte ne peut étre arrétée ni méme rétardée par les eonséquences de cette' crise superficielle qui natteint, en réalité, que la spéculation. Pa- reille situation ne peut 'en rien nuiré 4 V'élé- ment essentiel de la richesse naturelle du pays, qui est l'Agriculture.

" Or, les travaux d'irrigation et d'appro- priation se poursuivent toujours avec' la-méme méthode et la méme énergie et promettent d'augmenter.chaque année I'étendue des terres productives ; le programmé de. ces travaux, congu et exécuté avec ordre, prévoit ainsi un développement progressif, pour de longues années encore. Seul un événement touchant directement le coton pourmiit provoquer une perturbation dans la situation écotfomique de l'Egypte ; mais cette crise ne durerait que ce que-durerait la cause qui l'aurait provoquée. Le pays a, en effet, une vitalité trop considé rable pour rester longtemps sous le coup d'une crise passée.

" Qu'une récolte soit mauvaise, la perte sera, gertes, sériétse pour le pays exclusive- ment agricole ; mais toute force humaine est impuissante contre ce danger, car il est impos- sible de le prévoir. D'antre part, une baisse considérable du coton pourrait également por- ter atteinte a la prospérité de la contrée, mais cette baisse devrait étre importante, car en ce momefit-le.coton égyptien se traite ai prix de. 20 talaris, alors qu'il y a trois années seule- ment les cours se tenaient a 12-14 talaris en- viron/et laissaient un bénéfice sérieux aux cul- tivateurs. "
En conclusion, la "Cote Hebdomadaire " recommande l'achat des -bonnes valeurs égyp- tiennes 4 leurs bas cours. actuels.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les sétionnaires de la Wardan Estate Co. sont prévenus'que le dénxiéme verse de 1 par action sur la troisieme emission de 10,000 actiojns faite en Mai 1906 doit etre effectue le 20 Juin courant aux guichets de l National Bank of Egypt.

div.head: H. DE VRIES AND BOUTIGNY LTD.
APPELS DE FONDS.
div.p: Le Conseil d'Administration a l'honneur d'informer MM. les Actionnaires qu'il a ete decide de faire l'appel du 3mw versement (5/par action) le 1er Juillet 1907, et celui du 4me et dernier versemeat (5/-) le 1er Septembre 1907.
Les versements devront etre effectues aux guichets de H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd., rue Kasr-el-Nil au Caire.
Il est reppele qu'aux termes de l'article 18 des Statuts toute somme non payee le jour de son exigibilite porte interet de plein droit en faveur de la Societe au taux de 9% l'an.
Le Caire, 11 Juin 1907.
Par odre
de Conseil d'Administration,
EW. Tester
Secretaire.

div.head: CEREAL MARKET
div.p: ROD EL FARAG (National Bank's Shoonah)
The Municipalities of Montpellier, Perpig-nan, Narbonne, and many smaller towns have resigned.
300 troops sent to Narbonne to maintain order were cheered by the demonstrators.
In the Chamber of Deputies debates lasted all day on the Government's measures of 28rd May, and will continue to-day, The Southern deputies denounced them as inadequate. (R.)
The Chamber, discussing the wine-growing crisis, rejected by 505 votes against 65 a pro- posal, presented by M. Jaurés, tending towards the nationalisation of wine-growing.
The resignation of the Municipalities con-tinue. (Havas)
Riots have occurred at .Montpellier: cafés have been sacked and chairs and tables, hurled at the troops: many arrests haye-been made.
The Minister of Finance has recommended the wine-growers to.combine and regulate the outpnt and abolish the production. of inferior wines. (Reuter)

div.head:
ORANGE RIVER COLONY.
LETTERS PATENT OF CONSTITUTION.

div.p: The Letters Patent of the Orange River Colony Constitution have been issued. They closely follow the lines of the Transvaal Con- stitution. The same reservations- have been made. (Reuter)
Sir H. J. Goold-Adams will remain Governor of the Orange River Colony.
The newspapers are generally hopeful that the spirit of the Dutch in the Orange River Colony will harmonise with the spirit repre- sénted by General Botha in the Transvaal.
(Reuter)

Honse of Commons,-Sir EsGrey, replying to several questions raised. by Mr. Robertson regarding primary schools in Egypt adopting a Europeanised curriculum, said that the Egyptian Government was fully alive to tlie educational needs of the country.. He con- sidered that no, useful purpose would be served by interference on the part of the Imperial Governinent but he would inquire what know- ledge of Arabic was required by British'officials in the Egyptian Ministry of Instruction. (R.)

div.head:
THE EULENBURG SCANDALS.
REVEALED TO THE EMPEROR.

div.p: The Crown Prince revealed to the Emperor the Eulenburg scandals. For a long time nobody had tlie courage to tell the Enrperor and it seemed that the Eulenburg clique would pre- dominate indefinitely. (Reuter)

div.head:
DEATH DUTIES IN AMERICA.
PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S OPINION.

div.p: President Roosevelt, speaking at Norfolk, Virginia, strongly advocated a drastic progres- sive inheritance tax. He did not believe. that either, country or individual benefited by the transmission of enormous fortunes accummlated in America enitirety. (Reuter)
It is declared that the purpose of the Franco Japanese agreement is to guarantee the status-quo in Asia, and not merely in the territories of France and Japan. (Reuter)

div.head: MOTOR BOATS ON THE NIGER.
div.p: A very interesting account has come to hand concerning what are probably the first 4notor boats of comparativel employed on the Niger and its tributaries, for carrying cargo and for purposes of communi- cation. These boats, \ the "Spider" and the "Sandfly," are canoe shaped vessels with -very blunt. bows and square sterns, flat-bottomed from end to end, with the exception of a slight rise fore 'and aft. They are 56 ft. long o.a., 9 ft. beam and only 12" draft, fully loaded. They were built entirely by Messrs: John I. Thorny- croft and Co. Lim:, of Chiswick, and. were each fitted with a Thornycroft motor, developing 50 B.H.P. on paraffin and-5#-B.H.P. on petrol. With the exception that the "Spider" is propelled by screws -in 'tandem, and the "Sandfly" by a stern wheel, the vessels are identical. The motors have four cylinders, 6" diam ; x 8" stroke, cast in 'pairs, with valves arranged symmetrically on either side, inlet to port and exhaust starboard. The valves are actuated by vertical tappets, fitted with rol- lers on their lower ends.

An-important featifte of these engines is their accessibility, obtained by the special form of inspection doors fitted to the crankcase. Two doors are fitted on each side, these, when removed, leave the interior entirely exposed, including the camshafts, which may be taken ont at the side instead of being withdrawn longitudinally. To facilitate this, the camshaft bearings are made in halves, the bottom part being carried by brackets in the main casting, and the tops being held in place by caps. The tappet rod guides are mounted on the res- pectiye cams, so that as soon as these are removed, the camshafts are left absolutely free, Another important feature is the arran- gement for running on petrol or paraffin, as desired.

A four-way connection is fitted in the indue- tion pipe, the two horizontal branches going to thé cylinders, the npgoing pipe leading to the paraffin vaporiser, and the. downtake pipe to the petrol carburettor, Each of the latter pipes is provided with a throttle, so that if the motor is started up on petrol, the' vaporiser throttle is kept closed, while if it is desired to change over to the heayier fuel aftér the engine has warmed up, the petrol throttle can closed, vnd the paraffin valve opened.

Ordinarily the paraffin -yaporiser is heated by the exhanstgases which are passed through it, but if no petrol is available for starting, the engine can be got running from eold -in about 10 minutes by means of a paraffin lamp used to heat the vaporiser.

Half compression cams are fitted to the exhaust cam shaft to facilitate starting up, it being easy to get up a fair speed by hand under this} condition, and as soon as the engine" rae to fire, the fall compression is given, when the motor picks up very quickly.

The firstof these boats, the "Spider" was completed and delivered to the Southern Nige- rian Goyertiment in the early summer of last year, and after incidental delays due to transport, was finally erected and launched at Old Calabar in Joly. The first trip was of four hours' duration on the 24th July. This was accomplished without a stop, and without the least trouble from the motor, -which used ordinary American paraffin exclusively. After this the boat was put into commission, making regular.suns, towing steel or else native canoes, and delivering mails, ete. A notable run was one of 384 miles made last August, this being accomplished in 48 hours 23 minis, or at an average of 7.68 miles per hour, The paraffin consumed was at the rate of 4.6 gallons per hour—an extremely economical figure under the exceptional conditions. No petrol whateyer was used on this occasion' also, and the engine and clutch gave absolutely no*trouble. Another very good performance was a journey of 60 miles from Itu to.Indibe beach (Afikpo), towing two fully loaded steel canoes, on December 25th and 26th last. This distance was vovered in 14 hours 50 minutes, or at an average speed ofabout 4 miles per hour against stteam.

The motor invariably 'starts as easily on paraffin as on petrol, and as the cost of the former landed at Calabar is exactly half that of the latter, the advantages ot using paraffin are enormous, more particularly so with the very low consumption shown above. 'The cost of fuelper mile works out at an average of about 7 1/2d. A circamstance which speaks remarkably well for the ease and simplicity with which this type of motor may be handled, is the fact' that hitherto inexperienced nati- ves have, within a very short time, mastered the details to the extent of being able to dis- mantle and re-assemble it, while the "Spider " has been running for days together, and several hundred of miles from its base, in charge of a native driver only.

div.head: EGYPT'S WATCH TRADE.
100 YEARS AGO.
div.p: The following extract from the "Times" of May 29, 1807, is interesting :-—

The watch trade has been doubled in Europe within the last 50 years. It increases with the progress of civilization, which renders the in- strament which shews and divides time nearly af precious.as time itself. If we may eredit a French comnfiercial agent's account of the trade in the aes, England, before the Anterrap- tion of her commercial relations with Turkey, used to sell annually 30 dozen watches-at Salon- ica, as many in the Morea, 300 dozen at Constantinople, 400 dozen at Smyrna, 150 dozen in Syria, 250 dozen in Egypt. Nineteen' out of twenty were silver watches ; the gold ones are not so easily sold. The average amount of the whole English watch trade in Turkey was valued at 110,000 I. sterling annually.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain David M'Leod,* ist Battalion Gor- don Highlanders, has been specially selected for service with the Khedive's Army in the Soudan, and on arrival at Khartoum will be attached to the Camel Training School. Captain M'Leod isa born. soldier like his countryman, the late Sir Hector M'Donald. He entered the service as a private soldier' and served in the ranks for nearly thirteen years previous' to getting his second lieutenancy in the Cameron Highlanders in 1900, and he got his company in 1905 by special promotion into the Gordons. His record embraces the Dongola Expedition, 1896 (medal with clasp); Nile Expedition, 1898, including the battles of Atbara and Khartoum, in which his daring bravery earned him a double mention in despatches, and the Distinguished Conduct Medal (two clasps) and he participated in the advance against and the final smashing of the Khalita up the Nile in 1899 (two clasps to the Khedive's medal), His eomunission came to him whilst with hisregiment at the front in South Africa and in addition to campaigning with the Canierons he-also saw service with the South' African Constabulary, his agtive duties embracing the operations in Orange Free State, the Transvaal—in the course of which he was wounded—and Orange River Colony (thentioned in despatches, Queen's medal with three clasps, and King's' medal with two clasps). He recently was employed with the King's African Rifles in Céntral Africa.

Captain H.P. Williams, who has jast been ppoinited to the dof the battleship Irresistible. on the Mediterranean station, owing to Captain Tufnell having been invalided home through a severe attack of rheumatism, has been in the service since July, 1871, was promoted lieutenant in 1880, Commander in 1893 and captain in 1898, and recently vacated the appointment of Commodore and Naval Officer in Charge at Hong Kong.

Maxse, C.B., DS.0., commanding the Coldstream Guards ; ''o be a ber of. the Fourth Class, Lieutenant Colonel the Hon W. Lambton, C.M.G., D.S.0., command." ing the 1st Battalion Coldstream' Guards ; To be members of the 5th Class, Lieutenants G.B.S. Follett and G.P. Dawnay, D.S.0.

The alarming reports about théander water damage tothemighty Dreadnought turn out to be largely exaggerations. That the rudder was damaged is perfectly true, but that she steered so erratically as to bea danger to her sister cruisers is stated to be absolutely without foundation. Better speed results are anticipated after her new propellors are fitted.

div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
